item.title: If Vladimir Putin has to destroy cities like Kyiv and Kharkiv in order to impose a puppet government on Ukraine, he will in an important sense have already lost the war https://t.co/kh8tkyfrAE
Ukraine has spent centuries trying to find a national hero. The past days have produced dozens, writes @akurkov for @1843mag https://t.co/HoVpNWX1Nj
After one week of a war that has killed more than 2,000 Ukrainian civilians, according to the Ukrainian government, Vladimir Putin now has a territorial trophy to show for it https://t.co/KBaQnfJMM4
Since it gained independence in 1991, Ukraine has struggled to find heroes around whom to build a national myth. But the past days have produced dozens https://t.co/bHkRbfS6nX

“Everybody must see now that President Putin will not be stopped with persuasion or sanctions,” writes Ukraine’s former defence minister. “The time has come to take the first really effective step and to impose a no-fly zone” https://t.co/EgEtMw1jqT
Civilians went to bed in a Ukrainian city and woke up in a Russian-controlled one. We report on the fall of Kherson https://t.co/h8rtF0ZQla
The Russian invasion of Ukraine is not going to plan. The president has made three key mistakes https://t.co/xFUI1wa56d

A no-fly zone “will stop Russia from launching devastating missile strikes, dropping bombs or undertaking large-scale air assault operations,” writes Ukraine’s former defence minister in a guest commentary https://t.co/V3oOHJSyGn

“Western politicians danced with Vladimir Putin (some of them literally) and retired to chair the boards of Russian companies,” writes Ingrida Simonyte. “These firms funded the Kremlin’s arms race and diverted billions to Mr Putin’s entourage” https://t.co/p6wwNbOqDc
If they believed President Putin’s goal was a modern economy that he would not jeopardise by invading Ukraine, they were wrong https://t.co/o3qkOFSUoL
Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, has become cooler than St Petersburg grime with his defiant social media videos https://t.co/fSzWWLmfam
A no fly-zone would “essentially mean the US military would be shooting down…Russian planes”, warned the White House https://t.co/wxGGJABSjS
Countries arming Ukraine “cannot fail to understand the degree of danger” they are flirting with, says Russia’s foreign ministry. Suppliers seem undaunted https://t.co/xjcKWIlZ8x
Xi Jinping and his government maintain a pose of pseudo-neutrality towards the conflict in Ukraine, but nobody doubts China’s pro-Russian lean https://t.co/FcVuILsVxH
The prospect of facing legal charges might possibly deter some of Vladimir Putin’s lieutenants from following orders to commit war crimes https://t.co/7LunhvEDM3
NATO countries say that a no-fly zone is too risky. But Ukraine’s former defence minister disagrees—and believes that it “could avert a humanitarian disaster” https://t.co/zlonplNvtG

"We stand with you, this is not your fault"—Malala Yousafzai sends a message to young people in Ukraine.
To mark #IWD2022, @Malala and @zannymb discuss how to improve the lives of women and girls everywhere.
Subscribers can sign up to watch here: https://t.co/Cg6G1x8syd https://t.co/LVYMJyICAn
Joe Biden is as unpopular as Donald Trump had become at this point in his presidency. He was in especially poor form, stumbling through both scripted lines and ad libs https://t.co/kK56kGdwa1
As Ukrainians flee the country, guns and missiles are entering. But delivering arms is hazardous. We explain how it is being done https://t.co/RlhB2RQ0go
After a little more than one year in office, the president is in a slump. His answers to America’s domestic ailments were unsatisfying https://t.co/RNTmMFzSvx
Volodymyr Zelensky has requested that the West “impose a no-fly zone over significant parts of Ukraine”. We explain what the measure is, and why it comes at a cost https://t.co/qmbAc6N4fU

♦️ Russia’s defence ministry claims that its forces have taken control of the port city of Kherson. Local authorities deny this.
♦️ Ukrainian officials say airborne Russian troops have landed in Kharkiv.
♦️ Putin must “pay a price”, Biden warns.
Catch up on Ukraine ⬇️
China is treading a very fine line on Ukraine, @gadyepstein—one of our China specialists—tells “The Intelligence” https://t.co/obJ53RC602
After images of Russia’s attack began to circulate on social media, the share of Britons in favour of sending weapons to Ukraine rose from 46% to 60% https://t.co/nxdiq8ebD7
Half a century after China blasted the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia, the world order is turned upside-down https://t.co/sANt1zmHp9
Three-quarters of Ukrainians aged over 13 are active on social media. They are the ones filming the videos of war that catch the world’s attention https://t.co/fzgbmNCtG1

Vladimir Putin’s nuclear threat shows how much is going wrong for him in Ukraine. Why won't Russia leave its neighbour alone?
Read our latest analysis on the invasion: https://t.co/Ku48sueqh2 https://t.co/yDCDgXLqFT

Even with sophisticated methods at its disposal, Russia has “very different” targeting principles from those of NATO countries, says an analyst at the Royal United Services Institute https://t.co/pVf20u31nX
Russia has not recognised the International Criminal Court since 2016, when the court classified its annexation of Crimea as an occupation https://t.co/nEFwDLRg6J
Volodymyr Zelensky is an avid user of social media—his Instagram following is the fifth-biggest of any world leader. Now other Ukrainian officials have followed his lead https://t.co/VvOTCxbsbO
“It’s not the fault of the Russian citizens,” said Vova, looking up from his phone, “it’s the fault of Putin.” @wendell23's dispatch from Ukraine in @1843mag https://t.co/Cvu5NkinfL
It is one thing to think Russia is in breach of international laws, quite another to bring any Russian, let alone its head of state, to the world court https://t.co/N3LeDySkaz
China and Russia agree that big countries should run the world https://t.co/KWC1Wgkmju
There is prima facie evidence that Russia has committed at least three of the four main crimes prosecuted by the International Criminal Court https://t.co/UMKCqzjQpE
Russia’s recent strikes in Kharkiv and other cities show little sign of any effort to identify enemy forces https://t.co/JwdfWmXae7
There is no serious doubt that Russia has broken international law in Ukraine https://t.co/hh92XqWnz7
On the morning of March 1st President Volodymyr Zelensky announced he was putting an experienced soldier in charge of governing the capital https://t.co/pJ7ZZqOiQG
Kyiv has the deepest metro station in the world. Now it’s being used as a bomb shelter. From @1843mag https://t.co/yDEkdyDuuu
The EU’s borders, which have been closed ever more tightly to most refugees since a big influx from Syria and Afghanistan in 2015-16, are opening up for Ukrainians https://t.co/zxzQJD1Yzj
The goal may be to spread terror https://t.co/3hYaS5jtzH
Ukraine’s capital is not yet surrounded, but may soon be https://t.co/hM3UxXsVTw
Volodymyr Zelensky said that the missiles that recently fell on Kharkiv were deliberately targeted at civilians and described the attack as a war crime https://t.co/JfESC9js1d
The Russian authorities have responded by tightening their grip on the internet https://t.co/31MNZAPCRX
After images of Russia’s attack began to circulate on social media, the share of Britons in favour of sending weapons to Ukraine rose from 46% to 60% https://t.co/sujpg4dhxI
But many are heading the other way. Scores of Ukrainians, most of them without military experience, are heading home to enlist https://t.co/DoNJwKTgpu
“We all help one another and try to comfort each other.” Since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine began “The Intelligence” has been speaking daily to a resident of Kharkiv https://t.co/DzE1HiWr7h
The Russian authorities have responded by tightening their grip on the internet https://t.co/J11NkN3YVO

Russian state-owned media organisations have been banned or restricted in many countries. But inside Russia, how is its propaganda machine talking about the war in Ukraine? We explain ⬇️ https://t.co/38JErSF03T
But the truth is breaking through https://t.co/CTVurOjmz6
For young people in Russia, opposition has long been met with intimidation. 1843 magazine met some of them last year https://t.co/Yckc6VIfHN
